The **shinythemes** package makes it easy to alter the overall appearance of your Shiny applications Here are screenshots of the same applications with different themes:


```{r echo=FALSE}
images <- c("default", "cerulean", "cosmo", "flatly", "journal", "readable",
            "spacelab", "united")

generateTabTags <- function(images) {  
  vapply(images, function(image) {
    # Capitalize first letter
    label <- paste0(toupper(substring(image, 1, 1)), substring(image, 2))
  
    sprintf('
      <li role="presentation"><a href="#%s">%s</a></li>
      ', image, label
    )
  }, FUN.VALUE = character(1))
}

generateItemTags <- function(images) {  
  vapply(images, function(image) {
    sprintf('
      <div role="tabpanel" class="tab-pane" id="%s">
        <img src="images/%s.png" class="screenshot-image">
      </div>
      ', image, image
    )
  }, FUN.VALUE = character(1))
}

output <- paste0(c('
<div class="image-frame">
  <div class="row">
    <div class="col-sm-2">
      <ul id="themeTabs" class="nav nav-pills nav-stacked">',
      generateTabTags(images), '
      </ul>
    </div>

    <div class="tab-content col-sm-10">',
      generateItemTags(images), '
    </div>
    </div>
</div>

<script>
  // Cycle through tabs automatically
  var tabChange = function() {
      var tabs = $(".nav-pills > li");
      var active = tabs.filter(".active");
      var next = active.next("li").length ?
                  active.next("li").find("a") :
                  tabs.filter(":first-child").find("a");
      next.tab("show");
      tabCycle = setTimeout(tabChange, 4000);
  };
  var tabCycle = setTimeout(tabChange, 4000);

  // If user clicks on a tab, stop cycling it and activate
  $("#themeTabs li a").each(function() {
    $(this).click(function (e) {
      e.preventDefault();
      clearInterval(tabCycle);
      $(this).tab("show");

      // Automatically start cycling tabs after a delay
      tabCycle = setTimeout(tabChange, 12000);
    });
  });

  // On page load, activate first tab
  $(function () {
    $("#themeTabs a:first").tab("show");
  });
  </script>
'), collapse = "\n")

knitr::asis_output(htmltools::htmlPreserve(output))
```


## How to use it

In your ui.R, use the `theme` argument to `bootstrapPage`, `fluidPage`, `navbarPage`, or `fixedPage`.  The value should be `shinytheme("<theme>")`; for example, `shinytheme("cerulean")`.

```{r eval=FALSE}
## ui.R ##
library(shinythemes)

fluidPage(theme = shinytheme("cerulean"),
  ...
)
```


Similarly, if you have a single-file app:

```{r eval=FALSE}
## app.R ##
library(shinythemes)

shinyApp(
  ui = fluidPage(theme = shinytheme("united"),
    ...
  ),
  server = function(input, output) { }
)
```


## The themes

All the themes are from http://bootswatch.com/, and are MIT-licensed.

* [cerulean](http://bootswatch.com/cerulean/)
* [cosmo](http://bootswatch.com/cosmo/)
* [flatly](http://bootswatch.com/flatly/)
* [journal](http://bootswatch.com/journal/)
* [readable](http://bootswatch.com/readable/)
* [spacelab](http://bootswatch.com/spacelab/)
* [united](http://bootswatch.com/united/)


## How it works

Bootstrap can use alternative CSS files in place of the stock `bootstrap.css` file. When the **shinythemes** package is loaded, it makes these alternate themes available to Shiny applications in a relative URL under `shinythemes/`.

The source code for shinythemes is available [here](https://github.com/rstudio/shinythemes).

## How to use other Bootstrap themes

If you want to use a Bootstrap theme that isn't included in **shinythemes**, you can include it in an app's `www/` subdirectory. The directory structure would be like this:

```
myapp
 |-- server.R
 |-- ui.R
 |-- www/
      |-- mytheme.css
```

Files in the `www/` directory are automatically made available to your app. Your `ui.R` file would look like this:

```{r eval=FALSE}
fluidPage(
  theme = "mytheme.css",
  ...
)
```
